summary: This is an email chain from July 2020 between FBI personnel and a forensic examiner regarding the status of evidence processing in the Epstein case. It discusses a spreadsheet inventory of seized devices, issues with physically failed drives requiring data recovery, and the discovery of approximately 71,000 empty files on initial devices.

persons.name: I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Appears as the primary forensic examiner coordinating the evidence processing, sending status updates and spreadsheets regarding seized devices from the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Evidence Status Update and Questions
events.description: An email was sent by a USAO NYS attorney to the forensic examiner (I. (NY) (FBI)) with questions about the evidence spreadsheet, confirming additional devices and inquiring about drives still being processed.

events.title: Forensic Examiner's Response on Evidence Status
events.description: The forensic examiner (I. (NY) (FBI)) responds to prior questions, confirming the spreadsheet is comprehensive, noting that software finding empty files is not unusual, and explaining that 2 servers with multiple drives have physically failed and require specialist recovery.

keyFacts: The document is an internal 2020 email chain concerning the forensic examination of digital evidence seized in the Epstein investigation.
A vendor reviewing seven initial devices found approximately 71,000 documents that are zero bytes (empty files), which the examiner states is not unusual for forensic software to find.
Two servers with multiple drives have physically failed, requiring specialist data recovery at FBI HQ, with success uncertain and the process described as potentially very long.
The correspondence references a detailed, color-coded spreadsheet inventorying seized devices by identifiers like NYC024328, NYC024367, and NYC027910.
The document is subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence and investigation details.
